content.description: A fun problem that works its way out of a roof seam. Plenty of feet on this one and don’t let the moss detour you, the inside of the crack is clean and sticky. We only worked the line out the roof, there could be a possible finish to the top via going left at the lip and following another hand sized crack to the top
content.protection: Gear to two fixed nuts as a rap station
content.location: From where the trail meets the wall head north, continuing along the wall the climb will be approx 150 yards from where the trail meets the cliff. Climb is located in a large rock shelter that stays dry in the rain.

content.description: A funky start leads to a ledge, take either the crack or shoot straight up the face with good holds to gain the small ledge. From the ledge go left past some questionable blocks and gain the awesome flake system take it to the top, belay from tree
content.protection: Gear to a large pine tree
content.location: This route can be found by following the walls directly across from Because I Got High, cross the drainage and hug the wall around the point just around the corner there will be a long ramp with a square arch in the middle on the gound level.The route is on the far right side just before the cliff band fades out

content.description: One of the best lines I have come across out here. Starts in a left facing dihedral that is a perfect finger crack with superb edging  and then ends through a flake that gradually gets wider until topping out at a pine tree ledge. P1:Take the 60’ finger crack to the ledge and belay under the roof (10-) P2: Follow the hand sized roof system to the edge of the flake then take off up a cruising flake to a small roof with loose blocks. Finish on an off-width crack with lots of air below your feet. (9+)
content.protection: All the gear- Rap from tree or walk off south
content.location: Follow the pink markers until you come to a beautiful corner. Left from Because I Got High

content.description: This less than beautiful line is an off-width that starts on a face behind a pine tree. Move through some intermediate holds to gain the beginning of the crack system. Didn’t top out on this one but there could be a possibility to finish though a fist sized roof 11+/12-??
content.protection: Gear (didn't top out but walked around top to rap clean 3 piece anchor)
content.location: When the trail meets the cliff line there are two obvious crack systems, one on the right and this one tucked behind a pine tree immediately to its left.

content.description: This branch of walls and hollows is very intricate and boasts many quality crack seams that are waiting to be climbed. Many arches are located on this stretch of sandstone and even a 60’ stand alone pinnacle called Cap Rock. (important note: DO NOT CLIMB ARCHES, OR CAP ROCK)
